abstract.text: Defines the basic behavior associated with all overlay views.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: An overlay view provides the visual representation of an overlay objectâ€”that is, an object that conforms to the
protocol. This class defines the drawing infrastructure used by the map view but does not do any actual drawing. Subclasses are expected to override the
method in order to draw the contents of the overlay view.

The Map Kit framework provides several concrete instances of overlay views. Specifically, it provides overlay views for each of the concrete overlay objects. You can use one of these existing overlay views or define your own subclass if you want to draw the overlay contents differently.
In iOS 7 and later, use the
to create overlays based on custom shapes and content. The only method subclasses are expected to override is the
method. However, if your class contains content that may not be ready for drawing right away, you should also override the
method and use it to report when your class is ready and able to draw.

method must be safe to run from multiple threads simultaneously. To improve performance, the map view may tile overlays that are large enough and distribute the rendering of each tile to separate threads.

abstract.text: Display map or satellite imagery within your app, call out points of interest, and determine placemark information for map coordinates.
An interface for associating content with a specific map region.
Represents a generic overlay that draws its contents using a Core Graphics path data type.
The shared infrastructure for drawing overlays on the map surface.
Defines the basic behavior associated with all overlay views.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the overlay view is ready to draw its content.
Draws the contents of the overlay view.
Initializes and returns the overlay view and associates it with the specified overlay object.
Returns the map point that corresponds to the specified point in the overlay view.
Returns the map rectangle that corresponds to the rectangle in the overlay viewâ€™s coordinate system.
The overlay object containing the data for drawing.
Returns the point in the overlay view that corresponds to specified point on the map.
Returns the rectangle in the overlay view that corresponds to the specified rectangle on the map.
Invalidates the view in the given map rectangle at all zoom scales.
Invalidates the view in the given map rectangle but only at the specified zoom scale.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an objectâ€™s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
